block.p: Clinton Says Colombia Aid Is to Fight Drugs Not Rebels President Clinton made a one-day visit to Cartagena to lend backing to Colombia's counter-narcotics effort, insisting that $1.3 billion in American military aid is limited to fighting drugs, not ending the Colombian government's battle with rebel groups. ''This is not Vietnam,'' he said, ''nor is it Yankee imperialism.''

A Government for Somalia Somalia's first president in nearly a decade, Abdikassim Salad Hassan, arrived safely in Mogadishu, escorted by more than 1,000 armed militiamen and greeted by tens of thousands of joyous Somalis, despite worry over threats by the warlords who have ruled for the last nine years.

Suharto Pleads Illness The former Indonesian leader was absent from the opening of his corruption trial in Jakarta today. Lawyers for the 79-year-old former president said doctors examined him this morning and had found him too ill to attend. The announcement was not unanticipated.

Kidnappers Suggest Talks A member of the Muslim rebel faction that kidnapped an American in the southern Philippines this week told a radio station that the rebels were prepared to talk with the United States, but only if China, Iraq, Libya and North Korea also took part. On the other hand, the rebel said, ''Maybe we will behead him.'' A State Department spokesman ruled out negotiations.

Koreas to Allow More Reunions South and North Korea agreed in principle to allow more reunions of long-separated families and to take other steps toward ending decades of animosity, news reports said. This month, South and North Korea sent 100 people to each other's capitals for reunions with relatives.

Germany Convicts Neo-Nazis Three young German neo-Nazis were convicted of murder for beating an African immigrant to death, and one received a life sentence, the harshest punishment under German law. The case has become a symbol of the virulence of anti-immigrant sentiment among many youths in the former East Germany.

Cheney Asserts Clinton Mishandled the Military Dick Cheney, the Republican vice presidential candidate and former defense secretary, delivered a harsh assessment of the condition of the armed forces under President Clinton, accusing him, and by association Vice President Al Gore, of ''running down'' a military that succeeded in recent conflicts only because of the military build-up of Republican administrations. He said the military is stretched over too many theaters and is hampered by low morale, low pay, inadequate training and unreliable weapons and equipment.
Candidates Stay With Themes Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush stuck to their messages, with Mr. Gore promoting his Medicare plans and Mr. Bush pledging more aid to college students.

Texas Death Sentence Voided A federal judge overturned the sentence of Delma Banks Jr., convicted of murdering a 16-year-old boy. The judge cited the ''dismal'' performance of Mr. Banks's trial lawyer and the failure to tell jurors that a state witness was a paid informer.
Aides Dispute Nixon Drug Use Two aides to President Richard M. Nixon, responding to assertions in a book, said they doubted he ever took the antiseizure drug Dilantin.

Emphasizing Food Safety The government says its meat inspectors spend too much time on jobs that processors could do themselves, like monitoring the water content of meat products, and it wants inspectors to focus more on stopping harmful bacteria.

Billion-Dollar Wildfires Costs of fighting Western wildfires will soon exceed $1 billion, federal officials said, and Congress may have to dip into the treasury for the second time this year to pay the tab.

Mercury Found in Homes Nicor Gas found traces of mercury in 44 suburban Chicago homes that use its natural gas, and it plans to inspect up to 200,000 homes for the toxic substance, which may have spilled when meters were updated.
Unions and Temporary Workers The N.L.R.B. issued a ruling that opened the door for many temporary workers to join unions at work.

Spectacular Fire Sweeps New Jersey Riverfront Fire engulfed an unfinished condominium complex, Avalon River Mews, near the Hudson in Edgewater, N.J., and spread to an occupied building. Several firefighters were treated for heat exhaustion and smoke inhalation.

Move to Reduce Truck Traffic New York City, having completed a $20 million modernization of a Brooklyn freight yard, is seeking bidders to revive the use of barges to float railroad freight cars between New Jersey and Brooklyn.
Grocers to Pay Immigrants Two Manhattan greengrocers agreed to pay nearly $100,000 in back wages to immigrant workers who sometimes received only $200 for 72-hour weeks, state officials said.

Weighing a Run for Mayor Geraldo Rivera, the longtime television journalist and the anchor of a talk show on CNBC, said he was considering running a ''totally self-financed'' independent campaign for mayor.
The Road to 'Artificial Life' Scientists have created a robot that designs and builds other robots, almost entirely on its own.

Through a Daughter's Eyes Margaret Salinger's book ''Dream Catcher,'' due out next week, reveals not only her own life but previously unknown and deeply intimate aspects of the life of her famously private father, J. D. Salinger.

Warning From Whirlpool Whirlpool, the largest home appliance maker in the nation, warned that profits would be sharply lower, partly because Circuit City will stop selling major appliances. It also cited price competition and an industry slowdown tied to slumping retail sales and a housing market weakened by higher interest rates.

U.S. Expands Tire Inquiry Federal regulators trying to determine how much Ford knew about defective tires used on its Explorers told the company to turn over information on any tire problems it knew of in 16 foreign countries.
Open Action, On and Off Court Venus Williams beat Kveta Hrdlickova, 6-1, 6-1 -- and said her schedule was too full just now for any challenge match with John McEnroe.
Damir Dokic, the father and coach of the 17-year-old rising Australian star Jelena Dokic, was barred from the Open after off-court confrontations with employees and officials.
